A Few Weeks Back in the Western World
entry.content:
My semester in Dakar ended about two weeks ago, and now I'm in Paris until the end of July.  Being back has given me some time to think about my time in Senegal and the most important things I'll take away from my three and a half months there.

There are two very important aspects about Senegal I'll miss, and I think we can all learn from here in the western world.

The first is the strength of the community. From interactions with taxi drivers, to merchants, to waiters, to students, there's a sense that everybody will take care of each other.  Senegal is one of the least touched countries by famines in the area because of people's willingness to help other in times of need.  Families are large and everybody helps if a member needs help.  And families aren't just blood related.  Close family friends and members of the community are also considered a part of the family.  So much so that I had friends who had aunts and uncles with whom they weren't sure how they were related.

Walking down the street, you talk to people and say hi to all the familiar faces you cross.  When someone tried to rob a student on our trip, the entire neighborhood was asking her if she was ok for weeks.  Even the people she had never talked to.  People look out for each other and there's a sort of connection you feel towards others in your community and neighborhood.

The second is how well the Senegalese separate money from happiness.  In a country where the majority lives with about $2 a day, I met so many more kind, relaxed, and genuinely happy people than anywhere else in the world.  And it's not just a happiness you feel when talking to people, its something you feel walking down the street.  It's a general feeling in the air where people are content with what they have, and happy to be alive.  Things move slowly and once you adjust to the general noise and chaos of the city, the vibe is actually very relaxed.  People don't worry about money and wealth, and I think as a result, are happier.

I think this second aspect about separating happiness from wealth stems from the first.  People's happiness doesn't come from the things they own, or even the things they do.  Instead it comes from those around them - from their community, their friends and their family.  And so after a couple weeks back in a country where people keep to themselves and walk down the streets with two headphones in staring at their feet, these are the two things I'll miss most about Senegal.

Anyway, I'm moving my blogging over to rsata.com/blog.  Yeah, I made a website.  Couldn't help myself.  Thanks for following these posts.  I want this blog to begin and end with Senegal so I can look at it 10 years from now and remember all the ridiculousness and straight up awesomeness of this semester abroad.

Reid out.

link.title: A Few Weeks Back in the Western World

entry.title: Festival in the Desert
entry.content:
Adding to the list of pretty awesome things we’ve done here, a couple weekends ago we went to the Festival du Sahel, a music festival in the Lampoul desert north of Dakar.  The setting was incredibly picturesque and we stayed in tents provided by the festival for a grand total of $30/person for the entire 2-day festival. 

Deserts get cold at night
Everybody knows deserts get cold at night, and this was no exception.  However, knucklehead (as my dads likes to say) college kids will be knucklehead college kids, and we forgot this essential rule of all deserts.  Needless to say, we froze our asses off in a major way.  The warmest thing anybody brought was a sweatshirt, so once the sun went down and music ended, we had to huddle together to avoid freezing to death.  Kind of like penguins in Antarctica.

It also didn’t help that we slept right on the sand.  You could rent mattresses there, but since they cost nearly as much as we paid for the tent, the sand worked just fine.  Sort of.  Not only is it cold as hell, but if you’re not sun drying on a hot day at the beach, it doesn’t make a great sleeping surface.

Musicians to check out
Despite the slight chill at night, we got to see some awesome musicians.  Unfortunately, the second day is around when I started feeling sick again (see post about malaria), so I didn’t stick around the stage till the bitter end.  However, here’s some bands to check out:
-Vieux Farka Toure
-Omar Pene

-Yemen Blues

Some new pictures too: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10204807677084251.1073741826.1008060589&type=1&l=d1089cccf3

entry.title: Got malaria, won.
entry.content:
A few days ago, I went to the doctor because I was feeling a little under the weather.  Turns out I had malaria.

Symptoms
Like most nasty illnesses, the symptoms for malaria are similar to those of a common cold.  Headache, fever, chills, nausea, etc.  However, it’s cyclical and the symptoms tend to appear every 2-3 days.  After getting sick twice in a week, I figured it might be a good idea to get it checked out.

Diagnosis
A quick blood test determines whether you’ll need to take a ridiculous number of pills or not.  When I took mine, I don’t think the doctor thought I had malaria since I wasn’t particularly sick at the time (remember, cyclical).  That might explain why she started laughing a little when she saw my results.

Treatment
I’m on a drug called Coartem.  I take 4 pills in the morning and 4 pills at night.  Common side effects include nausea, diarrhea, decreased appetite, dizziness, abdominal pain, fatigue, palpitations, etc. etc. etc.  Without getting into too much detail, I had several of these, and it was not pleasant.

The doctor also prescribed some other stuff to help with the fevers and nausea, but I think those made it worse since the side effects for those closely resembles the above list.  The first day I took a personal record 16 pills, but have since cut back to only the ones I really need.

Myths
Malaria is a huge problem all over Sub-Saharan Africa and parts of Asia.  It kills hundreds of thousands of people every year and I’m not downplaying how serious of a problem it is.  However, from my experience and the people I’ve talked to, it’s another one of those things that is hyped up by western media.  Before coming here I thought that if you got malaria, you’d die, or have serious life-long health problems.  That’s not the case.  My pill diet cured me in 3 days, and the treatment is pretty standard.  Nearly everybody here has had malaria at some point in their lives, and it’s entire treatable.  Malaria is only dangerous when left undetected, especially in young children.  Unfortunately, that’s the case in many areas of the world.


So after 30+ pills, lost weight, and too many movies, I’m all better.

entry.title: Sine Saloum Pt2
entry.content:
A few weeks ago, we went back to the Delta, this time for “research.” 

A whole new meaning of the word “hot”
On our second day, it was 106.  I have a difficult time with anything over 75, so this was particularly challenging.  Swimming in the Delta practically felt like a bath since the water is so shallow, and it almost felt like we had warm water where we stayed.

Dancing
Not sure how we keep getting stuck doing this, but we did a lot of it.  Once with a youth performance group, another time at a baptism, and a final time with a bunch of kids and some tamtam drummers.  Like usual, we all made complete fools of ourselves, but had an excellent time doing it.

Overall, I think each one of us was blown away by the amount of work being done in Sokone.  They are cleaning up their city and making enormous progress in environmental protection, and sustainability. 


Which is why I’ve delayed writing this post.  Since our return, we’ve submitted and received a grant to return to Sokone after our trip is over to research and support sustainable oyster farming.  Why oyster farming?  Several reasons.  Oyster farming is one of the main sources of revenue for Sangako, a smaller neighboring village.  In addition, oysters grow on mangrove roots, and if not farmed correctly, the entire tree dies when its roots are cut.  Sangako is doing a ton to replant mangroves, and farm the oysters in a way that does not kill the tree.  We thought this was pretty cool, and applied for a grant from L&C.  We ended up receiving a couple thousand dollars to return to the mangroves.  Most of the money will buy material for the villagers to increase sustainable production methods.

entry.title: Updates
entry.content:
My posting has slowed a little.  With 2 weeks left, school work has increased and my spare time is spent doing other things.  However, I'll update you (family) soon.  

This weekend, I'm heading to the desert to go to a music festival.

In the meantime, here are a few pictures I uploaded from the past few weeks:
https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10204807677084251.1073741826.1008060589&type=1&l=d1089cccf3

entry.title: Politics, Law, Corruption
entry.content:
The biggest monument in Dakar is the African Renaissance Monument, built by former president Abdoulaye Wade, and completed in 2010.  It is made of bronze and at 49m tall, it is the tallest statue in Africa.  It also looks a bit like something you would have expected to find in Soviet Russia.  Not surprising since it was funded and built by North Korea.  Many criticize the statue for its style and high cost at a time of economic trouble (nearly 30 million US dollars).  In addition, Wade claims that since the statue was his idea, he is entitled to 35% of all profits.  In many ways, the statue represents Wade’s personality and political career.





Wade was many things, but above all, he was controversial.  He was known for his extravagant spending, and always travelled in style.  Some of his friends and allies included political leaders around the world including former president George W. Bush.  Many of his critics complained about his lavish lifestyle that included big houses, fancy cars, and private jets.  In addition, his entourage was very wealthy, traveling in luxury cars and lots of other nice things.  In a country where much of the population lives under $2 a day, this kind of behavior was often criticized, and was part of the reason why Wade lost the 2012 elections. 

Many also criticized Wade for nepotism.  Karim Wade, his son, was an extremely powerful minister, and Wade was grooming Karim to become the next president.

While he may have been a little (very) corrupt, Wade did many good things for Senegal, investing tons of money in infrastructure and development.  For example, the reason it no longer takes 3 hours to leave Dakar is due to the freeway built under Wade.  In addition, he developed the rural villages by building schools and youth centers.  Many of his projects were very visible and a testament to Wade’s ability to attract foreign investment. 

In addition, Wade further cut Senegal’s dependency on its former colonial power, France.  Senegal received its independence in 1960, but under the first two presidents, was still very dependent on France for money and other aid.  Wade changed this by finding investors in the Middle East and East Asia.  He created an image of Senegal that was no longer dependent on its former colonizer.  Wade’s party was often called “Sopi” meaning “Change” in Wolof, and Wade held true to that promise.

When Wade declared his controversial third bid for presidency in 2012, much of the population was outraged, and demanded change.  The financial crisis had severely weakened the Senegalese economy, and people refused to continue looking away from Wade’s high spending.  Many people spoke out against Wade in the 2012 elections, most notably a youth movement called “Y’en a Marre.”  It is said that Macky Sall, Wade’s successor, won not because people voted for him, but because they voted against Wade.  After losing the election, Wade peacefully stepped down and faded from Senegalese politics.

Unfortunately, Sall has not brought the change that many Senegalese had hoped for.  You can actually use the word “Macky” in conversation when referring to something that is stalling, somebody who is lazy, or just anything shitty in general.

Not only that, Macky Sall came to power under Wade’s regime, and as a result, does not have a clean sheet in terms of how he acquired his wealth.  Nonetheless, Sall swore to remove corruption from government.  Whether this is actually the case is debatable, however, one it is certainly less visible now than it was under Wade.


And now, the story continues.

In 2013, Karim Wade was arrested on corruption charges.  He was abroad at the time, but upon hearing the accusations, returned immediately to Senegal to fight the charges.  He was arrested and has been in jail for the past two years.  Many have criticized this arrest, saying it was done for political reasons.  Karim is a strong opposition leader, and was expected to run (and probably win) the 2017 presidential election.  While there is no doubt Karim became very rich due to his political connections and power, the charges against him are also faulty.  He is being forced to prove his innocence rather than the prosecutors prove his guilt.  In this case, the idea of “innocent until proven guilty” is the other way around.  In addition, there has yet to be any confirmed evidence proving that he stole money from the government.  Every accusation thrown against him has never been proven, and as a result, many have criticized his being held captive for over two years. 

Here’s an article explaining why the CREI (the special court accusing Karim) is full of shit: https://www.fidh.org/International-Federation-for-Human-Rights/Africa/senegal/15634-senegal-crei-a-special-court-which-does-not-guarantee-the-right-to-a-fair
The “legitimate fight against corruption is being conducted by a court that has all the attributes of a special court which violates the rights of the defense and does not guarantee the right to a fair trial…”

Public opinion in this case is very divided.  Many believe that Karim is guilty, but disagree that he should be held for this long without any real evidence against him.  Many also believe that his arrest is political, and that Macky Sall is eliminating a powerful opponent for the next election.  So what to do with a political leader being rightly judged for corruption, but by a body that throws any illusion of a fair trial out the window?  That’s more or less the debate going on here.

About a month ago, former president Wade returned to Dakar to get his son out of prison, and took the opportunity to raise all sorts of hell against the current government.  Not only that, he has promised that he will not let his son be convicted, and that if he is, he will “set fire to Dakar.” 

About an hour ago, Karim Wade was convicted and sentenced to 6 years in jail, eliminating him as a candidate for the 2017 election.  He must also pay nearly 230 million dollars back to the state.

entry.title: Food
entry.content:
Chebbu jenn
Classic Senegalese dish.  Rice, fried fish, muscles, carrots, potatoes, some other vegetables I don’t know the names of.  I eat this, or some variation of it, around 3-4 times a week.

Lax
Sort of like polenta, but they cover it in a sweet, milk-based sauce.  Easy to make, and we usually eat this on Sunday nights since lunch those days is usually late and enormous.

Daxin
A traditional Wolof dish and the only dish I can think of off the top of my head that I had some serious difficulty with.  The feeling of putting a piece of meat in your mouth and immediately realizing the horrible mistake you’ve made is never pleasant.  The dish consists of a peanut and rice based mash – similar to the consistency of mashed potatoes, but a little drier.  This part is pretty good and the one time we ate daxin I mostly stuck to this non-meat section.  That is because the meat is sheep head and intestines.

Yassa
Fried fish or chicken with onions on rice.  This is typically the dish they serve us (and all westerners) at restaurants when we go in a big group.  Not complaining though.  Yassa is delicious. 

Fish
They fry the fish whole and make vertical cuts along the body so that it’s easy to tear off into chunks with a spoon.  It takes a little getting used to, and I’m just now starting to get fewer bones in each bite.  My pops is a pro.  He somehow manages to take half the meat off the fish in one motion, without a single bone.

Snacks
I’ve lowered my peanut consumption for egg sandwiches.  For 50 cents, you get a fried egg on bread with onions and salt.  I think I’ve had one every weekday for the past month… 

We also recently discovered that you can get barbecue sandwiches at this stand not far from school.  We had gone there previously to snack on some steak skewers, but yesterday ordered the sandwich version.  For $1, you can get half a baguette full of freshly barbecued steak, hard-boiled egg, mayonnaise, and onions. 

They also make beignets on the side of the road on our walk home.  4 for less than a quarter makes them the obvious choice for a light snack if the line isn’t too long.  Like the steak guy, they cook them right there on the sidewalk.

Anyway, we’re headed back to the delta tomorrow for our individual trips.


Also, some new pictures: https://www.facebook.com/4tadayuki/media_set?set=a.10204807677084251.1073741826.1008060589&type=3

entry.title: Sine Saloum Delta
entry.content:
Last week we went to the Sine Saloum Delta for a couple nights.  It’s hard to believe we’re getting academic credit for this one…

Things we did: sightseeing, kayaking, swimming, dancing, tree climbing, pottery.  It was basically a mini vacation.  But hey, I’m not complaining.  It was nice getting doted on for a few days. 

Schedule
In very un-Senegalese fashion, they gave us a schedule for the trip.  In very Senegalese fashion, we never did any of it within less than 2 hours of the scheduled time, and also didn’t really follow it at all. 

Kayaking
When you go kayaking in the US they always go through the safety precautions, give you a life vest, bla bla bla.  Not the case here.  No lifejackets, no safety talk, and within 5 minutes we’re paddling away in the delta.  Sort of.  Our paddles were not really paddles, but more like oversized salad spoons, which made moving anywhere pretty difficult.  One of the boats also had a hole in it so that one sank…  As a result all the kayaks had an extra person on the back. 

Pottery
No pottery wheels, and they hand make their own clay.  And we made pots!  Well they let us go at it with the clay until the whole thing was about to collapse before stepping in to save it.

Tree Climbing
We visited a guy who climbs palm trees, gets juice from the fruit at the top of the tree, and then turns it into wine and oil.  Apparently it only takes 2 days for the raw juice to turn alcoholic.  We tasted some freshly gathered and it already tasted like wine… 

Anyways, I took a bunch of pictures: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10204807677084251.1073741826.1008060589&type=1&l=d1089cccf3


We’re heading back to the Delta next week for research.  This time though we get to take public transportation and stay in not a hotel.  Definitely looking forward to going back and maybe I’ll do my research on swimming and kayaking.

entry.title: Miscellaneous #2
entry.content:
RIP Tapha
There was a goat we named Tapha that most of us passed on our way to school (see here).  Very mellow goat.  Nice personality.  The other day there was a baptism that a few people attended.  They ate goat.  Can you guess where it came from?

Thief
A few weeks ago, somebody tried to rob a girl on our trip while she was walking home at night.  She was walking with a group, but was by herself for literally the last minute of the walk when the attempted robbery happened.  Since she is a complete bad ass and refused to give up her bag, she ended up being dragged a few yards kicking and making a ton of noise until neighbors came out to help.  She got a bit scratched up, but is doing fine and no serious harm done.  They caught the thief and what ensued gave us a look into Senegalese street justice. 

When a thief is caught, it is a completely normal and accepted thing for every guy in the neighborhood who hears the yelling (or who hears that there is a thief) to come beat the crap out of him.  And by beat the crap out of, I mean they usually beat the guy to death.  If the thief is caught armed, zero chance he lives.  In many neighborhoods and villages, they don’t even send a police car – just an ambulance to take the body away.  In this case, the thief was lucky and only got beaten to a pulp and lost all of his teeth before the police came.

In Yoff, the fishing community in the northern part of Dakar, the tradition is to beat the thief up, put him in a rice bag, tie the top, and drop him in the middle of the ocean.

Tea (aataya)
The other day, Samba taught us how to make tea.  Aataya is served in small cups and there is a whole process that goes into preparing the cups.  There needs to be some foam, or else the common thing to say when receiving a foamless cup is, “why are you giving me a cup of lion’s piss.”  The process takes a while and is a bit messy since you basically pour the tea from one cup to another until all the cups have some foam in them.

We decided to speed up the process: put tea in a bottle, shake bottle, pour into cups.  Definitely a faux pas.


In other news, we’re headed to the Sine Saloum Delta tomorrow (Thursday).  Looking forward to getting out of Dakar for a few days and seeing the Senegalese countryside.  More to come + some pictures.

entry.title: Out and About (a little past my bedtime)
entry.content:
Nightlife starts late.  Anybody who’s anybody doesn’t get to a club before 2 am.  For our first clubbing experience (a few weeks ago) we went to a place called Le Voyageur, located in a not so excellent neighborhood called the Medina.  Walking up to the place, the bouncer immediately spotted Kimball, the other guy on my trip, wearing shorts and flip-flops and would not let us in.  After a bunch of arguing, the bouncer would not budge so while half our group continued arguing with the guy, we went about finding ways in. 

Attempt 1
There were a bunch of people hanging around the entrance to the club and when they saw we needed pants they immediately jumped on the opportunity to scam us into some overpriced knockoffs.  One group tried selling Kimball some sweatpants that probably wouldn’t have gotten him in anyway.

Attempt 2
Liza, a girl in my group, was wearing leggings under her dress.  At this point we were desperate so Kimball put on Liza’s leggings under his shorts and tried again.  Predictably the answer was still no, except at this point we had attracted the attention and amusement of all the locals hanging out around the front.  While Kimball and Liza were changing in an alley, a guy who lived about 10 minutes away came and offered to go grab Kimball some pants and shoes.  Also to warn us that the guy walking towards Kimball and Liza was going to try and rob them.  Nice guy.

Attempt 3
After changing into some pants that didn’t really fit, we ditched the shorts and flip-flops at a store that agreed to watch his stuff.  Third time’s the charm and we made it in.

Inside the club
-Observation 1: A lot of dudes.  At least 75% of the people in the club were guys.  I think most families don’t let their daughters go out as much, so competition is fierce. 
-Observation 2: Combination of old American pop music, some Senegalese stuff, and an occasional French rap.
-Observation 3: Americans can’t dance.  I’m already pretty bad at dancing, but when I’m surrounded by other people who aren’t very good either it kind of makes up for it.  Not the case here.  The Senegalese have a way of making every movement look cool and in control.  A lot of the time they move less and more slowly than us out of control foreigners, but every movement is deliberate, perfectly times, and just looks cool.  They also have a way of only moving one part of their body making the effect more pronounced.  On the other hand if I want to move my knee in any attempt of a dance move, half my body ends up coming with me and it ruins the effect.  Fun times though.

link.title: Out and About (a little past my bedtime)

entry.title: Miscellaneous #1
entry.content:
Frisbee
Frisbee in Senegal?  Yeah, not really a thing, but on Sunday afternoons, there’s a group of American ex-pats that goes to play at a nearby field.  We went looking for the field during the week to make sure we could find it, and were greeted by high walls and a security guard who wouldn’t let us in.  After further investigation, it turns out that Ebbet’s Field is owned by the US embassy and reserved exclusively for embassy workers and their guests (which is why we can go on Sundays because there are embassy people there).  That Sunday we made it into the place and basically discovered mini America.  Ebbet’s field is the only place in Dakar I’ve seen grass.  And to add to the huge perfectly maintained grassy field are beach volleyball and basketball courts, hammocks and picnic tables.
Anyways, Frisbee is fun and takes place in one of the only grass fields in Dakar.

N’Ice Cream
There are a couple ice cream chains here, but N’Ice Cream is the best in terms of flavor and name.  They have a million different flavors and the inside looks a little like a froyo place.  The ice cream is also really good and they have a flavor called Obama.

GRAG
Part of our program involves internships around the city.  I’m working at the Global Research Advocacy Group (GRAG), an NGO that evaluates government projects to help them improve their effectiveness and outreach.
It’s been a cool experience so far.  We’ve been translating an evaluation of a UNICEF water sanitation project, and helping prepare the PowerPoint that will be presented to the governments of Ghana and Burkina Faso. 

Papa’s Wolof lessons
Papa has taken it upon himself to make sure I can speak some Wolof before I leave.  He made me a little worksheet which is great and super useful, but which I will also be tested on next week.  Excellent.

Mail

Some people in my group got packages the other day, which offered the rest of us a little glimpse into the shit show that is the Senegalese postal service.  If you’re not with a Senegalese person, chances are they will make you pay twice – once for the customs fee, and another time because they are ripping you off and stealing your money.  Also, if your package has valuable items, you might not ever get it.  For example, an American at my house had a computer shipped here and my host dad told his connection at the customs office that if that anything happened to that package, it would be an international scandal between Senegal and the US.

entry.title: A Day in the Life
entry.content:
8:30
Breakfast typically consists of bread and coffee.  Sometimes a beignet here and there.

9:00
Walk to school takes about 15 minutes. 
Say hi to the familiar faces on the way.  Especially Mel the monkey and Tapha the goat. 


Tapha
9:15 – 1:00
Technically class starts at 9, which in Senegalese time is around 9:15.
Classes are two hours long and we have a lot of them.  It’s been a bit of an adjustment getting used to class hours that are more like high school than college.  Gone are the days of 2 hours of class.  Now, 6-8 hours is the norm.

1:00 – 3:00
Lunch.  Depending on the day, we have anywhere from two to four hours for lunch.  That gives us plenty of time to head home to eat and mentally prepare for the afternoon marathon of classes.  Lunch is typically the biggest meal of the day, so Mama always tells me I need to eat well, and Papa tells me I need to fatten up in preparation for my wrestling match.  Every meal he keeps reminding me I’m going to fight one of those huge Senegalese wrestlers.  I just laugh it off until today he told me the date.  February 29th.  Hmm…

3:00 – 7:00
Class.  Depending on the day we get out anywhere between 5 and 7.  On early days, there are a couple bars we stop by on our way home.  The beer of choice here is either Flag or Gazelle.  Choosing between the two is a bit like picking between Busch and Bud Light.  I tend to go for the Gazelle (a grand total of 25 cents cheaper at 1000CFA = less than $2) while my “pumpkin peach ale” loving compatriots, go for the slightly less fratty Flag Spéciale.

9:00 – 11:00
Dinner, tv watching with family, sleep.

Repeat.

A few things:
-Babakan is a common name here and it is awesome.
-Playing frogger across the three-lane highway to and from school has become a little less terrifying.
-I’ve eaten enough peanuts in the past two weeks to stock a southwest flight.  They sell them in little bags on the side of the road and they’re dangerous.

LASTLY, uploading pictures to these posts was taking way too long so I made a fb album:

https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10204807677084251.1073741826.1008060589&type=1&l=d1089cccf3

entry.title: Weekend
entry.content:
Last weekend: an island and a 3-hour car ride around Dakar.

Saturday we went to Île Ngor, famous for Akon’s house, and scenes from The Endless Summer.  To get there they cram you on a tiny little boat to cross the bay.  The island is very nice, and the vendors are way less pesky than on Gorée.  We walked around for a bit and were standing on a cliff watching some people surf when someone with a microphone and a camera came to talk ask us about the competition.  Competition?  We had no idea it was a competition.  Good job Toubabs, but apparently our “interview” went on air on a local radio station.  Once again, we’re famous.  Apart from that we spent most of the day lounging on the beach.


Sunday we took a three-hour bus ride around the city to see the sights and whatnot.  Pictures below.

entry.title: Lámb
entry.content:
Lámb is the Senegalese version of bareknuckle boxing with a little wrestling, and some spiritual stuff on the side + dancing and a whole crazy preshow madness scene around the ring with really loud music, all of which as a Toubab witnessing this for the first time is terrifying, exciting, interesting, and overall, totally awesome.

Pretty much everything that happens in and around the ring also happens in the stands.  Great fun.

Dancing
Everybody was dancing.  They had really loud live drumming and singing that didn’t let up the entire time we were there.  Naturally, fans form their own drum corps in the bleachers to add to the noise.

Fighting
The winner of a Lamb match is the one who gets their opponent on the ground (technically four limbs or back touch the ground) by punching, tackling and sometimes, picking up and throwing.  Basically, two huge, ridiculously ripped guys face off and proceed to bare knuckle box / wrestle until one gets hit enough times in the face to allow the other one to force them to the ground.

As one would expect with a crowd of loud, amped up, 15-30 year old guys watching other guys fight, the testosterone in the place was off the charts.  Which led to lots of trash talking between opposing fighter’s fans.  We somehow found ourselves between two such fan bases.  Once they started waving money at each other and calling the other fans’ fighter weak, the group above us started pushing down over the benches to get at those punks below who clearly needed a lesson in boxing ring etiquette.  Sitting at the outer most edge of our group, I was practically in the middle of the stampede…  I stuck it out until my glasses almost came off and I got elbowed in the head when I politely bowed out and got the hell away. 

Spiritual stuff
A big part of the preparation for the match is the spiritual stuff.  Fighters pour a bunch of liquid over themselves and each has their own pre-game routine.  They also wear charms to protect themselves and give them strength.

We noticed that the loser of the match was always helped out of the ring by his possy, regardless of whether or not he could walk.  It was a little bit like shaming them after they got beaten to a pulp.  “Ha!  Not only did you get the shit knocked out of you but your people have to come drag you away because you’re too weak to carry your own fat ass.”

TV
Being the large group of (almost all) white people that we were, we ended up on television.  I got a message from my host brother telling me they zoomed up on our group and were commenting on how it was great that foreigners were getting into the sport.  We’re famous!


Next up: whatever we do this weekend (something involving another island and a tour around Dakar with one of our professors).
  


Some fans.  The people in orange are supporting some fighter who always wears orange.
One of the fighters dancing/warming up, surrounded by his possy.
Two opponents touching fingers as a sign of sportsmanship.  Just kidding, they're about to smash each other's faces in.
Our view.

entry.title: Toubabs do Bargaining
entry.content:
So if you’re wondering what the hell we’ve actually been up to for the past few days wonder no longer.  On Saturday we took a trip to Gorée Island.

For the below to make since, I should tell you that Toubab is the Wolof word for white person.  Not insulting, just the way they’re called.  Technically not applicable to me, but guilty by association I guess. 

A little introduction.  Gorée Island is where they used to send off slaves to the Americas.  The main attraction there is the house where slaves were kept before getting on the boats, but to sound like an old person, the island itself is beautiful, and the views are stunning – for this, see pictures below.

What I want to talk about mostly are the vendors there.  Holy crap, they’re terrifying.  It’s pretty normal to have people try and sell you things in the city, but the vendors on Gorée Island are in a whole different league.

Toubabs make friends
On the boat before we even got to the island, we met some very friendly women who asked about our stay in Senegal, etc etc.  Nice conversation and they mentioned that they owned shops on the island and that we should stop by and say hi.  We laughed it off and told them we’d see them when we got there.  Seemed harmless enough. 

Toubabs walk around
When we got to the island, we were met by a throng of vendors who followed our group around trying to sell us jewelry, jerseys, and other paraphernalia.  That’s when I met Zéna (or however you spell it) who told me to stop by her shop later. 

Toubabs spotted by vendor “friends”
As we were finishing up lunch, a vendor came over to try to sell us a jersey.  Quickly a crowd of other vendors spotted us and flocked to our table, including our good friends from the boat, and Zéna.

Toubabs dragged to market
As we left the restaurant, Zéna told me that I was an “independent man” and should leave the other girls in the group (there is only one other guy, Kimball, who at that point had literally run away from someone trying to sell him a jersey or something) because “freedom and independence is very important.  And you are independent man.  Come with me because you free.  Come see Zéna shop.  I give you good price.”  By the time we left the restaurant, Zéna was practically dragging me to her stand. 

Toubabs split up by vendors – kind of like a zebra herd and lions (cheetahs?)
Before I knew it, I was at Zéna’s stand.  I think the other toubabs were also dragged in separate directions.  She showed me all the jewelry and fabric she had, then when I expressed interest in one of the fabrics she got very close and whispered in my ear “I give you excellent price.  10,000 CFA (about $20).”  No friggen way, lady.  We argued for the next 5 minutes until eventually she gave me half of the fabric for 3,000 CFA.  I was definitely still getting ripped off but first negotiation under my belt and I felt OK about it. 

Toubabs overwhelmed by vendors
I walked out of the market and was immediately dragged to a new stall by Mamie, one of the vendors we met on the boat.  Since I “promised” her I would take a look at her shop, we went over there and I somehow ended up getting a couple bracelets.  What the hell am I going to do with bracelets??

At that point, the other vendors knew the fish were biting.  I practically had to run away from 10 of them all yelling at me that I had “promised” them I would look at their stands.  I told one of them I would stop by later if I had time, and he somehow knew I had 2 more hours on the island.  Time to look down and walk fast.  Eventually, I made it to the beach where a couple other stragglers were waiting, and we made our escape to the other end of the island.

Toubabs have a great time
Yes, the vendors were overwhelming, pushy, rude, and guilt trip you into impulse buying, but overall, Gorée Island is beautiful and we had a great day there.  Here are some pictures.


Next up, we go to a Lámb match: bare knuckle boxing + wrestling, Senegalese style.



First step onto the island.  Nice little beach and harbor with really cool fishing boats.

La Maison des Esclaves - the little bright spot between the two stairs is where the slaves exited the building to the ships taking them to the Americas.

Slaves were separated by age and gender.  This is where the children were kept.

The entrance to the old fort.  Now it's a museum. 

View from the top of the fort/museum 

A courtyard + vendor walking away with the shirts he was selling us

A lot of the streets looked like this (but this was the nicest one).

View from the top of the hill overlooking the island.

Cool looking building.

entry.title: Home Sweet Home
entry.content:
Welcome to my family.

Mama
The way the house is run in Senegal is as follows: the mother runs the show.  Period.  Most households are like this.  Mine has a seat on the couch in the living room that I’ve never seen anybody else sit in, and she typically has the couch to herself with us peasants on the other two.  It’s hard to explain her control of the household because it is only something you feel.  When I got here, Mama made it very clear when I got there that any problems I had, or anything I needed, to come and see her.  Her house, her rules.  She’s awesome. 

Papa
I see Brahem, my host father, for about 30 minutes a day.  He usually arrives right before dinner, but doesn’t stay up long.  We typically eat around 8:30 or 9, and he goes to sleep soon after.  The family is Muslim, and I’m pretty sure he wakes up at 5:30 for the morning prayer.  Papa likes to teach me Wolof.  Everyday when he gets home, he says something to me in Wolof that I understand (usually something like “jere si jamm” – did you pass your day in peace), then something I don’t.  That pretty much concludes the lesson of the day.
Most recent Papa time: watching the Fresh Prince of Bel Air, dubbed in French.  He loved it.  Awesome.

Ibou & co.
Ibrahem (everybody calls him Ibou), the youngest of my host brothers is 24.  He goes to night classes a few days out of the week, and all day Saturday.  When I see him, we usually hang out in the living room, or the other living room that has Wi-Fi.  He’s super cool and helps me out with any questions I have.  I’m a little terrified of Mama, so I usually go to him if it’s something small. 

I see the older brother and sister at meals.  The sister, Rama, is in town – she lives in Paris now.  Their uncle is also in town from Paris.

Meals
I typically eat lunch and dinner with other members of the family.  Breakfast is more of a solitary thing as everybody gets up at different times.  When we eat together, we eat out of a big plate in the middle of the table.  Everybody eats out of the section facing them.  The meat or other “goodies” are in the middle.  When Mama is there, she is the one to cut up and distribute the middle out to the rest of us.  When I’m feeling gutsy, I’ll venture out of my section a little bit to snag a stray potato…
In almost every meal there are onions, and the meat of choice is fish.  Senegalese eat a lot of rice, potatoes, bread, and fish.
Another thing about meals is that when you are finished, you leave the table.  Waiting for everybody else to finish is not a thing here.  I think the reason you do this is to make room for somebody else to sit down in your spot and eat.  Many times, the family doesn’t all eat together, but more like in waves.
Oh and when you eat, you can only use your right hand.  I’m left handed, so it has taken some getting used to, but I’m starting to get the hang of it.


Next up: Gorée Island and vendors trying to sell us things in ways that would put the Wolf of Wall Street to shame.




Some of the family.  From right to left: Mama, Oumar (uncle), Rama (sister), Ibou (brother).  Pictured in the living room, the most popular hang out spot of the house.



The other living room where they have guests sometimes.  This is also where the father sometimes goes to enjoy some peace and quiet to watch his TV. 



My room.  It's messier now...



Yep, we're all still alive.

entry.title: Welcome to Dakar
entry.content:
I’m going to keep these descriptions short and sweet, because if I go into too much detail about the color of the sand, the color of the walls, or the play by play of our walk through downtown, you’ll be bored to death…  And most likely not read this at all.  So here are just a few observations, and pictures from our little walks around the neighborhood and downtown (15 minute taxi ride south).

Heat
Doii it’s hot.  But their idea of cold weather puts things in perspective.  They tell us that it’s winter and the weather currently is much colder than usual.  Many of the locals are wearing jackets, and some even have scarves or beanies on.  It’s like 75…

Smell
Everything, good or bad, smells a lot.  Whether it’s fruit from the street vendor, fish cooking at a restaurant, or raw meat from the butcher stand, it always smells.  I’m not saying it smells bad at all, it is just very noticeable.  We walked through a market and every few steps the smell went from vegetables to meat to fish to fish/meat to vegetables to definitely chicken then back to vegetables. 

Dust
It’s very dusty.  The streets are pretty much the only part of the city that is paved, and we spent most of our walks on sand, or in the street.  It’s also windy.  So, dust. 

Cars and crossing a street
The relationship between drivers and pedestrians is a bit like a game of chicken.  There aren’t really cross walks, so you kind of just cross whenever there is a gap between two cars.  Cars don’t like to stop.  Ever.  But on the other hand, Senegalese people are always very relaxed and like to take their time when they walk.  Which makes crossing the street interesting.
Traffic laws are also not much of a thing here.  Rarely are there lines on the street so it’s a bit of a free for all when it comes to passing.  Four way intersections don’t seem to have stop signs…  So multiple cars flying into an intersection, a couple breaking at the last minute and honking at each other, is quite common.
Lastly, cool thing about taxis, you bargain with the driver for a price before getting in the cab.

Goats
It seems like a fair number of Senegalese families (not mine unfortunately) have goats.  They leave them in the street or on the roof.  I was a little surprised when I walked around the corner straight into a goat…  Then more surprised when I walked on the roof deck (you have to walk on the roof to get to my room) and saw some neighboring goats staring back from one roof over.

Smiling
Smile, nod, say hi to people.  The family and community is an extremely important part of Senegalese culture, so it’s important to greet people, especially those you see regularly around the neighborhood and on the walk to school.  I think I’ve almost gotten the hang of it, but I’m sure I still say hi to people with a huge smile on my face and they wonder why the hell I’m smiling at them (even though they always say hi back! – possibly out of pity for the stupid American).

Loitering always allowed
A lot of people hang out on the street.  Unlike in many other countries, where people seem to always be going somewhere, a lot of Senegalese hang out on corners, doorsteps or in front of stores.  Also, 24h doormen are quite common, adding to the street hanger outers.

My name is Oumar Gaye
On our second walk, we went around the neighborhood where most of us are living.  In Senegalese fashion, we walked straight into several of our host houses to briefly meet whatever member of the family was there.  At my house, the door was open (pretty common if somebody is home) and I met my host mother, Mame Ngone Gaye (I call her Mama), and my host brother Ibrahem Gaye (he goes by Ibou).  My name does not translate well to Wolof, so within about 30 seconds of entering the house, I was promptly given a new one by Mama: Oumar Gaye.  It has taken a few days to get used to it, but now, in the house, I am Oumar. 


Next post: more pictures and my host family.




The Baobab Center - We meet here every morning, and will take classes here.



The biggest Catholic Church in Dakar.



Entrance to the Kher Mer Market



Mayor and other important people's office

entry.title: Getting to Senegal
entry.content:
15 hours of plane time, 30 hours of awake time, 3 hours of visa problems, and 1 under average sized chair later, I’m here on a couch watching Kouthia with my host brother, a popular Senegalese comedian on TV.  Unfortunately its in Wolof so I have absolutely no idea what is going on.  But it they tell me it’s hilarious. 

How did I get here?

A tiny chair
So I’m of the opinion that economy class seats are actually not that small.  Sure, after 10 hours they’re a little uncomfortable, but overall, not bad.  This time however, different story.  They told me I would be in an exit row.  Nice because it was one without a row in front so I could stretch my legs all flight.  Bad because it they had to make it narrower to make it fit in the exit row.  When I saw the chair I actually laughed out loud…  Take a normal sized seat, make it a few inches narrower, and that’s the pitiful thing I was sitting on for 10 hours, tucked away against the wall of the airplane.  To put things in perspective, this thing made me feel like my ass was the size of a small bus.

We had a direct flight to Paris, a four-hour layover, then a final 5ish hour flight to Dakar. 

The Senegalese visa process
Well actually, first you have to make it to the officers making the visas…  A process that makes congress look like the holy grail of efficiency.  To me, it was spectacular.  It’s hard to visualize, but they basically had the line set up in a way that enabled all of us to cut the 30 or so people who waited their turns (for literally hours) like good citizens.  To make matters worst (or better depending on how you look at it), we were stuck standing for hours, with a bunch of pissed of, sarcastic, middle-aged French men complaining, and trying to speed up the process by yelling at each other and the people who worked there.  While one of the them jokingly ordered a hamburger and fries, another told the woman to get her superior, and two argued about which African countries had better visa processes.  We pushed and shoved, and moved the barriers keeping us in line, until finally, two and half hours later, we made it to the front.
To get a Senegalese visa, you typically apply and pay online, print the receipt, and pick it up at the airport.  Sounds easy right?  Famous last words.  After a few minutes of hiding behind a computer, the border official told me that I could not enter the country because my visa wasn’t approved.
Our conversation (in French):
Officer: “Do you have the paper?”
*I hand him a letter from my school explaining our situation
Officer: “Wrong paper.”
Me: “Which paper?”
Officer: “The paper.”
Me: “What does it looks like?”
Officer: “Approval letter.”
Me: “No, I don’t know what you mean.”
Officer: “Well I can’t let you in.”
Me: “Why not?”
Officer: “You can’t come in.”
Me: “Why not?”
Officer: “Your visa wasn’t approved.”
Me: “Why not?”
Officer: “It wasn’t, you can’t come in.”
Me: “What do I do?”
Officer: “You can’t come in.”
…
Our conversation looked like this for about 5 minutes, and once he realized I wasn’t going anywhere, he brought me over to talk to his boss, who in about 30 seconds explained that we ordered a visa that they could not approve at the airport, and since it had not been approved, we would have to buy a 3 month visa, and add the 6 month visa we had already paid for, to the 3 month after one it had expired.  Yes, this sounds absurd and makes absolutely no sense, but after getting yelled at by a scary Senegalese lady at midnight on a Sunday night in a foreign country, we stopped arguing and bought the damn thing.

Backpacks for a reason
Last blog post I was wondering why the hell every single person was using a backpacking backpack.  Answer: sand.

From the airport, we were greeting by the people running our trip, and by a bus that took us to a hotel to spend the first night.  After 24 hours of traveling, it was time to sleep.


I’m writing this after my first full day of being here.  We’ve walked around, seen some goats, almost get run over, almost run other people over, and finally meet our host families.  Oh and my new name is Oumar…  All that in the next post.

entry.title: Preparation
entry.content:
Mental Preparation
Throughout the semester, we’ve had a few meetings to get us prepared for this trip.  As you’d expect, they included various information about the visa application, culture, and how to not get malaria.  We also had a dinner with last year’s group where they cooked one of the local dishes whose name I can’t remember, and probably couldn’t spell anyways (if you’re curious, it was fish and rice). 

Physical Preparation
-Yellow fever
-Hepatitis A & B
-Typhoid
If you’re planning on going to Africa anytime soon and you have to take typhoid medicine, get it in the shot version, not the pills!  Even though the pills last 5 years and the shot only lasts 2, the pills are a pain.  Besides crappy side effects like fevers and nausea, you have to take the pill on an empty stomach.  Sounds easy, but when you’re starving, your head hurts, and you can’t eat it really sucks.  You also have to take it every other day around the same time for a week (4 pills).  So pain in the ass x4. 
-Malaria
Malaria pills are expensive and I saved $600+ by buying the generic Malarone.  You have to take it every day, but one of the weekly alternatives may include lucid dreams and hallucinations…  Pleasant.
Of course, the other malaria prevention is bug spray.  I have 100% deet which I’m not sure is more harmful to me or the bugs…  But mosquitos beware.  You bastards are going down with me.

What’s with everyone bringing a backpack? 
Within our group and from asking around, it seems like everybody going abroad is bringing a backpacking backpack instead of a suitcase.  I’m bringing a giant suitcase.  Did I miss something? 

Africa is not one giant country + Ebola
Whenever I tell people I’m going to West Africa, they ask me about Ebola.  Ebola is not in Senegal, and Senegal’s response to their only case is viewed as an “instructive lesson” for other countries dealing with the outbreak.  Seriously, I should be more worried about malaria, and the flu.
Contrary to many people’s views of Africa, Senegal is one of the more developed countries, has a stable government, good foreign relations and a vibrant capital.  Whatever view of Africa many have of safaris, wildebeests, machetes, and the lion king, Dakar is not that (there’s even a cologne called Dakar for crying out loud).  From what I’ve heard, and Wikipedia, Dakar is a big city of over 2 million with a thriving art and music scene. 


I leave the day after tomorrow!  Stay tuned.

entry.title: A little introduction
entry.content:
Friends, family, and randos who somehow stumbled upon this blog, welcome and hello!

As some of you already know, I’m heading to Senegal this semester from January 10th to April 20ththrough the study abroad program at Lewis & Clark College.  I figured making a blog would be the easiest way to keep my (slightly) worried family and procrastinating friends updated on all the excitement, drama, food, culture shock, perspectives, and adventures that are inevitable in three and half months abroad. 

Just a little background.  There are 10 of us heading to Dakar in a few short days.  The program is focused on Sub-Saharan Francophone Culture, and is based in Dakar, the capital of Senegal, and the most western tip of Africa.  All of our classes will be taught in French by professors from the local university.  We’ll be living with host families, who at the moment are a complete mystery.  Still couldn’t tell you what my hosts’ names are.  Which could be great, given the fact that the first few days are always super awkward.  Especially if you’ve already used up all the “how’s the weather” and “what’s your favorite food” topics over email…  Anyways, we’ll also be taking a few trips around the country including a visit to the Gorée Island, Saint Louis, and the Siné-Saloum Delta. 

Apart from that somewhat less professional version of the trip description on the L&C website, I’m pretty clueless as to what to expect.  We’ve had some prep that I’ll talk about in another post, but apart from that, I have no idea.  That’s a common theme among many of my friends also going abroad to places they have never been to.  We’ve all heard stories and talked to previous participants, but there is always the unspoken understanding that we won’t really get what they’re telling us until we go and see for ourselves.  And so I think it’s fair to say, I’m pretty clueless, but I like it that way.

Over the next few months, I’ll be posting pictures and stories from my shenanigans overseas.  I hope you enjoy!

Reid
